description: From Middle English blowen, from Old English blāwan (“to blow, breathe, inflate, sound”), from Proto-West Germanic *blāan, from Proto-Germanic *blēaną (“to blow”) (compare German blähen), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰleh₁- (“to swell, blow up”) (compare Latin flō (“to blow”) and Old Armenian բեղուն (bełun, “fertile”)).

entries.meaning: A strong wind.
examples: We're having a bit of a blow this afternoon.

entries.meaning: (informal) A chance to catch one's breath.
examples: The players were able to get a blow during the last timeout.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, US, slang) Cocaine.
examples: Synonyms: see Thesaurus:cocaine

entries.meaning: (uncountable, UK, slang) Cannabis.
examples: Synonyms: see Thesaurus:marijuana

entries.meaning: (uncountable, US Chicago Regional, slang) Heroin.
examples: Synonyms: see Thesaurus:heroin

entries.meaning: (informal, vulgar) A blowjob; fellatio.
examples: Synonyms: see Thesaurus:oral sex
His girlfriend gave him a blow.

entries.meaning: (nautical) An instance of using high-pressure air to empty water from the ballast tanks of a submarine, increasing the submarine's buoyancy and causing it to surface.

verbs.description: blow (third-person singular simple present blows, present participle blowing, simple past blew, past participle blown)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To produce an air current.
(transitive) To propel by an air current (or, if under water, a water current), usually with the mouth.
examples: Blow the dust off that book and open it up.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be propelled by an air current.
examples: The leaves blow through the streets in the fall.

entries.meaning: (figurative) To direct or move, usually of a person to a particular location.
(transitive) To create or shape by blowing; as in to blow bubbles, to blow glass.
(transitive) To force a current of air upon with the mouth, or by other means.
examples: to blow the fire

entries.meaning: (transitive) To clear of contents by forcing air through.
examples: to blow an egg
to blow one's nose
The submarine blew its main ballast tanks.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to make sound by blowing, as a musical instrument.
(intransitive) To make a sound as the result of being blown.
examples: In the harbor, the ships' horns blew.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, of a cetacean) To exhale visibly through the spout the seawater which it has taken in while feeding.
examples: There's nothing more thrilling to the whale watcher than to see a whale surface and blow.
There she blows! (i.e. "I see a whale spouting!")

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To  burst or explode; to occur suddenly
examples: Get away from that burning gas tank! It's about to blow!

entries.meaning: (transitive, with "up" or with prep phrase headed by "to") To cause to explode, shatter, or be utterly destroyed.
examples: The demolition squad neatly blew the old hotel up.
The aerosol can was blown to bits.

entries.meaning: (transitive, historical, military, of a person) To blow from a gun.
(transitive) To cause the sudden destruction of.
examples: He blew the tires and the engine.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To suddenly fail destructively.
examples: He tried to sprint, but his ligaments blew and he was barely able to walk to the finish line.

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang) To recklessly squander.
examples: I managed to blow $1000 at blackjack in under an hour.
I blew $35 thou on a car.
We blew an opportunity to get benign corporate sponsorship.

entries.meaning: (transitive, informal, idiomatic) To fail at something; to mess up; to make a mistake.
examples: I blew it and forgot to start the spaghetti, so I had plenty of sauce and no pasta.
Good luck, and don't blow it!

entries.meaning: (intransitive, stative, slang, sometimes considered vulgar) To be very undesirable.
examples: Synonym: suck
This blows!

entries.meaning: (transitive, vulgar) To fellate; to perform oral sex on (usually a man).
examples: Who did you have to blow to get those backstage passes?
Synonyms: see Thesaurus:give head

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang) To leave, especially suddenly or in a hurry.
examples: Let's blow this joint.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make flyblown, to defile, especially with fly eggs.
(intransitive) (of a fly) To lay eggs; to breed.
(obsolete) To spread by report; to publish; to disclose.
(obsolete) To inflate, as with pride; to puff up.
(intransitive) To breathe hard or quick; to pant; to puff.
(transitive) To put out of breath; to cause to blow from fatigue.
(dated) To talk loudly; boast; brag.
examples: He didn't just set around and try to out sweettalk[sic] somebody; he got out and out-fit somebody.  He wouldn't be blowing when he told his boys how he fit for the woman he got.

entries.meaning: (UK, slang, archaic) To expose, or inform on.
examples: Synonym: grass up

entries.meaning: (slang, informal, African-American Vernacular) To sing.
examples: That girl has a wonderful voice; just listen to her blow!

entries.meaning: (Scientology, intransitive) To leave the Church of Scientology in an unauthorized manner.
(slang, colloquial) To flatulate or defecate.
examples: Uh, oh! I gotta blow!

description: From Middle English blo, bloo, from Old English blāw (“blue”), from Proto-Germanic *blēwaz (“blue, dark blue, grey, black”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰlēw- (“yellow, blond, grey”). Cognate with Latin flavus (“yellow”). Doublet of blue.

adjectives.description: blow (comparative blower or more blow, superlative blowest or most blow)

entries.meaning: (now chiefly dialectal, Northern England) Blue.

description: From Middle English blowe, blaw, northern variant of blēwe, from Proto-Germanic *blewwaną (“to beat”) (compare Old Norse blegði (“wedge”), German einbläuen, Middle Dutch blouwen). Related to block.

entries.meaning: The act of striking or hitting.
examples: Synonyms: bace, strike, hit, punch
A fabricator is used to direct a sharp blow to the surface of the stone.
During an exchange to end round 13, Duran landed a blow to the midsection.

entries.meaning: A sudden or forcible act or effort; an assault.
A damaging occurrence.
examples: Synonyms: disaster, calamity
A further blow to the group came in 1917 when Thomson died while canoeing in Algonquin Park.

entries.meaning: (Australia, shearing, historical) A cut made to a sheep's fleece by a shearer using hand-shears.
(Australia, New Zealand) An outcrop of quartz from surrounding rock, thought to indicate mineral deposits below.
(television) Synonym of button (“the punchy or suspenseful line of dialogue that concludes a scene”)
examples: The blow is important because it transitions the reader and eventually the audience from one scene to another.

description: From Middle English blowen, from Old English blōwan, from Proto-Germanic *blōaną (compare Dutch bloeien, German blühen), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰleh₃- (compare Latin florēre (“to bloom”)).

entries.meaning: A mass or display of flowers; a yield.
A display of anything brilliant or bright.
A bloom, state of flowering.
examples: Roses in full blow.

verbs.description: blow (third-person singular simple present blows, present participle blowing, simple past blew, past participle blown)

entries.meaning: To blossom; to cause to bloom or blossom.
